description: From Latin sine (“without”) + cūrā (“care”) in beneficium sine cūrā (“benefice without care”).

entries.meaning: Requiring no work for an ample reward.
examples: By the act of union (1800), the offices of Irish secretary, a sinecure post, and lord lieutenant's secretary were combined.

entries.meaning: Having the appearance of functionality without being of any actual use or purpose.
A position that requires no work but still gives an ample payment; a cushy job.
(historical) An ecclesiastical benefice without the care of souls.

verbs.description: sinecure (third-person singular simple present sinecures, present participle sinecuring, simple past and past participle sinecured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put or place in a sinecure.
